qas.question: What were Sumerian temples known as?
What was the central pond in the forecourt of a Ziggurat for?
Who were the rooms on either side of the aisles in the temple for?
What was the mudbrick table in the temple for?
Where did the Sumerians usually locate their granaries and storehouses?
What feature of temples provided fresh drinking water?
What was stored away from the temples?
what was a precursor to pyramids?

context: <a0_0>Ziggurats<a0_0/> (Sumerian temples) each had an individual name and consisted of a forecourt, with a <b5_0>central pond<b5_0/> for <a1_0>purification<a1_0/>. The temple itself had a central nave with aisles along either side. Flanking the aisles would be rooms for <a2_0>the priests<a2_0/>. At one end would stand the podium and a mudbrick table for <a3_0>animal and vegetable sacrifices<a3_0/>. <b6_0>Granaries and storehouses<b6_0/> were usually located <a4_0>near the temples<a4_0/>. After a time the Sumerians began to place the temples on top of multi-layered square constructions built as a series of rising terraces, giving rise to the <b7_0>Ziggurat<b7_0/> style.
